abstract.t: This document described best practices for publishing domain name pricing data by registries for consumption by registrars and other parties.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: As the DNS namespace expands, the need for registries to publish pricing information in a uniform fashion becomes more acute. Currently, registries publish this information in a variety of formats and though a variety of media, making it difficult for registrars to automate the process.

This document proposes a standard protocol for publishing domain name pricing information in the standard format described in . Adoption of this protocol and the format in by registries will facilitate the uniform automation of the exchange of pricing information between registries and registrars, which will aid with the adoption of new gTLDs.

section.title: Conventions Used in This Document
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in RFC 2119.

section.title: Security
section.t: As the published pricing information is commercially sensitive information for both the registry and registrar, the files MUST TLS. Preferably, the registry SHOULD use TLS 1.2 , though TLS 1.0 and TLS 1.1 MAY be supported for backwards compatibility.

Equally, registries SHOULD use HTTP Authentication to control access to the published information. Policy regarding how credentials is at the descretion of the registry, but it is RECOMMENDED that registries use the IANA ID of the registrar as the username.
